caption: What a performance by the !On 6 April 2025, the took the stage and captured our hearts at the SiGlap 60 Carnival, a two-day intergenerational community event, which was honoured by the presence of Dr , Minister in the Prime Minister's Office, Second Minister for Education, and Second Minister for Foreign Affairs. A heartfelt thank you to Dr Maliki for his steadfast support as one of the five East Coast advisors!A memorable moment was when the band performed "You & I", an original song written by two members of the band in 2024 to commemorate the Yellow Ribbon Project's 20th anniversary. The piece carries a powerful message of resilience, hope, and finding the strength to look beyond mistakes and move forward together. Thank you to everyone who turned up, cheered them on, and stood in support of second chances. Rehabilitation happens one step (and one note) at a time. SecondChances YellowRibbonProject BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject

caption: The SPS-YRSG Corporate Advance at saw over 800 attendees, comprising staff and community partners. Themed Forward Corrections: Innovate and Collaborate, the event highlighted ongoing efforts to build community partnerships that uplift inmates employability.At the event, YRSG highlighted two initiatives: Career Circles programme, launched to equip inmates with the skills to set career goals and prepare for job searches. About 300 inmates have undergone the programme since its inception. Project Beyond Hiring initiative, introduced to enhance support for both employers and ex-offenders in the workplace.These initiatives aim to support the gainful employment of ex-offenders, enabling successful reintegration and longer-term desistance.Together, lets stride toward a more inclusive societyone where ex-offenders are given a second chance in every aspect of their lives and career development. YellowRibbonSingapore SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances CorporateAdvance2025

caption: lovewins youareenoughThis March 8th, International Womens Day, I was invited to speak at Changi Female Prison. I brought my mum, making her dream come trueto return not as a prisoner, but as a beacon of hope. Mum was incarcerated in Changi from the mid-70s to 1983 for drug offenses. She turned her life around, living drug-free for decades. Her presence that day was a powerful message: *Its never too late to change. You are enough.* The inmates asked raw, valid questions about change and forgiveness. Mums life was the answerproof that no matter how far you fall, you can rise again. This day also reminded me of my familys 30-year journey to reconciliation. My parents divorced, and Dad remarried, but by Gods grace and effort, weve built a close-knit family. I adore my step-siblings, Adam and Andrea, and cherish the love we share. Ive been blessed with an incredible support systemmy overprotective brother, Spencer, who stepped up as a parent, my amazing aunties, uncles, and my Granny, who taught me, *Nothing is impossible, and family is worth fighting for.* To the ladies at Changi: Keep the faith. Believe in yourselves. Your past doesnt define your future. Never give up. And to anyone reading: Family and love are worth fighting for. Healing is possible. Grateful to AGAPE and Changi Prison for this meaningful opportunity. Forgiveness Reconciliation SecondChances Hope Family NeverGiveUp LoveWins

caption: Our Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) STAR Bursary Networking Session on 1 March 2025 was a meaningful gathering of students, families, funders, and case workerscoming together to celebrate achievements, forge connections, and support one another. Through gratitude activities, a mental wellness workshop, and heartfelt conversations, we remain committed to walking alongside our students on their educational journey.A special thank you to our funders, case workers, and the YRF Secretariat for being part of this journey, and to Mr Matthew Wee Yik Keong, YRF STAR Bursary Chairman and Deputy Commissioner of Prisons (Operations & Rehabilitation) of the , for inspiring our students as they embark on their next chapter. We look forward to empowering more students on their path to rehabilitation and reintegration. YellowRibbonSingapore YellowRibbonFund SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

caption: YRSG held its first YR Connects of the year, celebrating The Power of Second Chances with employers who make a difference in the lives of ex-offenders. Their commitment to inclusive hiring and supportive workplace practices help create a society where providing second chances leads to lasting changes. Our special guest Associate Professor , Minister of State for Home Affairs & Minister of State for National Development thanked the employers and reaffirmed the importance of the community coming together to support ex-offenders reintegration. A heartfelt thank you to all who believe in the power of second chances. Lets keep building a more inclusive and brighter future together. YellowRibbonSingapore SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances
cleaned_caption: YRSG held its first YR Connects of the year, celebrating The Power of Second Chances with employers who make a difference in the lives of ex-offenders. Their commitment to inclusive hiring and supportive workplace practices help create a society where providing second chances leads to lasting changes. Our special guest, Associate Professor, Minister of State for Home Affairs & Minister of State for National Development, thanked the employers and reaffirmed the importance of the community coming together to support ex-offenders' reintegration. A heartfelt thank you to all who believe in the power of second chances. Let's keep building a more inclusive and brighter future together. #YellowRibbonSingapore #SG4SecondChances #BeyondSecondChances

caption: The Yellow Ribbon Project partners with various organisations to support the reintegration of ex-offenders into society. One of such organisations which has demonstrated strong support for the Yellow Ribbon cause is . This festive season, Geneco has partnered with a non-profit organisation which partners to conduct family programmes for inmates to help to break the cycle of intergenerational incarceration and co-created the book, Love Beyond the Walls: Till the End of Time.Written by inmates participating in the family programmes facilitated by NLS and illustrated by former inmate artists from CANVAS, this heartfelt book features 10 stories that convey love and hope from the incarcerated parents to their children. You can pre-order at: If you would like to receive the book in time for gifting this Christmas, the book will be available for purchase at Genecos Till the End of Time pop-up event, happening outside Ngee Ann City, from 12 to 18 December, and 100% of proceeds will go directly to NLS.Limited edition Yellow Ribbon Project 20th Anniversary Hope Bears will also be available for purchase at the event, and 100% of proceeds will go towards supporting the Yellow Ribbon Fund. Image credits: Geneco YellowRibbonProject YRP20 YRPHopeBears YellowRibbonFund Geneco GenecoSG TillTheEndofTime SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

caption: A HUGE thank you to all runners who put their best foot forward and ran in support of a Nation Beyond Second Chances! On 1 September 2024, Guest-Of-Honour, Senior Minister , flagged off this years Yellow Ribbon Prison Run. He was joined by Minister for Digital Development and Information & Second Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs .ylm. This event welcomed about 11,000 local and overseas participants, taking part in 10km or 5km run categories. This year also saw the introduction of the inaugural Kids Dash category, as we seek to inspire the younger generation about the importance of giving second chances!The 15th edition of the Yellow Ribbon Projects (YRP) flagship event also coincided with YRPs 20th anniversary celebration. As we move beyond two decades of championing second chances, the YRP hopes to expand collaborations and encourage more community partners, while also empowering desistors to play a more active role in leading projects and initiatives.In addition to the record number of participants for the YRP run event, the run had also raised a total of $557,370.00, which was the highest ever since the event was introduced! These funds will go towards various programmes that support the rehabilitation and reintegration of inmates and ex-offenders, as well as support their families and children to prevent inter-generational offending.For participants who completed the 10KM Competitive Run , you can check out your race timings here: in the next few days. Thank you for being part of the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run, and see you next time!yellowribbonprisonrun 2ndchances SG4SecondChancesYellowRibbonProject YellowRibbonSingapore aNationBeyondSecondChances YRPR24 YRP20
cleaned_caption: A HUGE thank you to all runners who put their best foot forward and ran in support of a Nation Beyond Second Chances! On 1 September 2024, Guest-Of-Honour, Senior Minister, flagged off this year's Yellow Ribbon Prison Run. He was joined by Minister for Digital Development and Information & Second Minister for Home Affairs. This event welcomed about 11,000 local and overseas participants, taking part in 10km or 5km run categories. This year also saw the introduction of the inaugural Kids Dash category, as we seek to inspire the younger generation about the importance of giving second chances! The 15th edition of the Yellow Ribbon Projects (YRP) flagship event also coincided with YRP's 20th anniversary celebration. As we move beyond two decades of championing second chances, the YRP hopes to expand collaborations and encourage more community partners, while also empowering desistors to play a more active role in leading projects and initiatives. In addition to the record number of participants for the YRP run event, the run had also raised a total of $557,370.00, which was the highest ever since the event was introduced! These funds will go towards various programmes that support the rehabilitation and reintegration of inmates and ex-offenders, as well as support their families and children to prevent inter-generational offending. For participants who completed the 10KM Competitive Run, you can check out your race timings here in the next few days. Thank you for being part of the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run, and see you next time! #yellowribbonprisonrun #2ndchances #SG4SecondChances #YellowRibbonProject #YellowRibbonSingapore #aNationBeyondSecondChances #YRPR24 #YRP20

caption: On 24 March 2024, the Department of Corrections of the Thailand Ministry of Justice organised their inaugural Yellow Ribbon Run Run For Relife! Graced by Police Colonel Thawee Sodsong, Minister of Justice, the event held at Nonthaburi Province was attended by more than 2,000 participants. Our SPS and YRSG staff participated in the event to show our support too! Run for Relife aims to raise public awareness of the need to give second chances to ex-offenders, generate acceptance for ex-offenders, and inspire community action to help ex-offenders reintegrate into society successfully. Funds raised from this event went toward a prisoner welfare fund that will support the prisoners rehabilitation and reintegration and their families. Join us in showing our encouragement and support for Yellow Ribbon Thailand! YellowRibbonProject WeAreEachOthersSecondChances SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

caption: On 24 March 2024, the Department of Corrections of the Thailand Ministry of Justice organised their inaugural Yellow Ribbon Run Run For Relife! Graced by Police Colonel Thawee Sodsong, Minister of Justice, the event held at Nonthaburi Province was attended by more than 2,000 participants. Our SPS and YRSG staff participated in the event to show our support too! Run for Relife aims to raise public awareness of the need to give second chances to ex-offenders, generate acceptance for ex-offenders, and inspire community action to help ex-offenders reintegrate into society successfully. Funds raised from this event went toward a prisoner welfare fund that will support the prisoners rehabilitation and reintegration and their families. caption: On 21 October, the Yellow Ribbon Appreciation and Awards Ceremony 2023 recognised 186 award recipients, comprising desistors, employers, community partners and other dedicated individuals, who provided invaluable support to inmates and ex-offenders in their reintegration journey. With its core theme of "Illuminating Journeys, Overcoming Barriers", the event celebrated the community's success in shaping a more inclusive society. Participants also had opportunities to network with others who shared the same cause. The event was graced by Guest-of-Honour Mr Chan Chun Sing, Minister for Education. Minister Chan, together with Mr Phillip Tan, Chairman of YRSG; Mr Rockey Francisco Junior, Deputy Commissioner (Policy and Transformation) of Prisons from the , and Mr Sunny Lee, CEO of YRSG; expressed their solidarity towards a shared vision by tying a yellow ribbon around the oak tree. Our sincere gratitude to every individual and organisation, as well as all the volunteers, donors, workplace advocates, employers, and desistors who have contributed to our efforts. caption: The biennial Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) Charity Gala Dinner, held on 3 February 2023, raised over $1 million in donations to support inmates, ex-offenders, and their families. Since its inception in 2004, YRF has disbursed over $19 million to assist 64,000 inmates and ex-offenders through initiatives like the YRF Skills Training Assistance to Re-start (STAR) Bursary, which enables ex-offenders with low income to pursue higher academic qualifications, and the Yellow Brick Road (YBR) programme, which provides case management services and support for vulnerable families with children. The event was graced by Guest-of-Honour, Senior Minister and Coordinating Minister for Social Policies, Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam, alongside over 106 generous corporate and individual donors who attended the event. YRF will continue to expand its support for inmates, ex-offenders, and their families to inspire hope and create an inclusive society. YellowRibbonFund BeyondSecondChancesSG4SecondChances

caption: Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG) successfully held its first outreach event this year on 13 January 2023. caption: On 18 July 2022, Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Network held its annual Summit 2022, themed Igniting Connections, Empowering Lives, to raise awareness and appreciation of CARE Network and its efforts in strengthening throughcare support for inmates and ex-offenders. CARE Network is co-chaired by Commissioner of Prisons and Chairman of YRSG.CARE Network's stakeholders, corporate partners, social workers and ex-offenders were invited to hear the key developments of the CARE Network and participate in panel discussions to share more about their experiences. A networking session was also held for community partners and social enterprises to share about their work and create collaborative opportunities.Special thanks to Guest of Honour Josephine Teo .ylm Minister for Communications and Information and Second Minister for Home Affairs, for highlighting the need to look beyond the immediate post-release rehabilitation of former inmates through new approaches and capabilities.Mrs Teo also expressed her appreciation for the work done by members of the CARE Network, which comprises over 100 community partners and supporters across various social service agencies, halfway houses and religious groups. With an effective aftercare support network, we can work together to help rebuild the lives of inmates, ex-offenders and their families and lower the recidivism rate. CARENetworkSummit2022 IgnitingConnections EmpoweringLives CARENetwork SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

CARE Network is co-chaired by the Commissioner of Prisons and Chairman of YRSG. CARE Network's stakeholders, corporate partners, social workers and ex-offenders were invited to hear the key developments of the CARE Network and participate in panel discussions to share more about their experiences. A networking session was also held for community partners and social enterprises to share about their work and create collaborative opportunities. Special thanks to the Guest of Honour, Minister for Communications and Information and Second Minister for Home Affairs, for highlighting the need to look beyond the immediate post-release rehabilitation of former inmates through new approaches and capabilities. caption: It has been 10 years since Aidil last celebrated Hari Raya with his family. Having been in-and-out of prisons six times, the 42-year-old shared that he was first incarcerated in 1998 for drug related offences. Distracted by the lure of drugs, he re-offended even after his first release. 23-years later, with unwavering support from his family, he is set on quitting his old ways.Aidil shares that he is grateful to be emplaced at the Jamiyah Halfway House and hopes it would signal a new beginning for him.The staff here are very understanding. We can approach them for help with our issues, like renewing our SingPass. Even the head (Mr Mohamad Faizal Bin Abas), hes like a father figure to me.Im really looking forward to my overnight home leave on Hari Raya, so I can be at home spending time with my family again. My parents have always been supportive of me, but I would still like to seek their forgiveness for the things Ive done. I also hope to spend more time with my son soon.For those in recovery, the support from family is critical. May Hari Raya be a time of reflection, togetherness and second chances for all.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

caption: In celebration of Mothers Day, 12 inmates participated in a project sponsored by SSA Culinary Institute to bake cookies for their families. It has been a difficult period for the inmates as open visits with their families could not be organized due to COVID-19 safety management measures. The day started with a demonstration by Chef Aishah from SSA Culinary Institute, followed by a hands-on session for the inmates. Their labour of love was also freshly delivered with the help of Bravehearts SRM Services Pte Ltd to convey their love for their families.It was great to see them so involved and curious. They wanted to learn more and asked many questions about the baking process. Seeing their interest makes me heartened to offer more of my knowledge. said Chef Aishah.Thank you to .institute and for partnering with Yellow Ribbon Project (YRP) and making this possible for our inmates and their families. Support from them as our community partners contributes towards the inmates rehabilitation and reintegration journey.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

caption: The Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition is one of the many initiatives that aims to equip inmate participants with skills training relevant to the Food & Beverage (F&B) Industries to enhance their employability. This years competition also marks Singapores first virtual cooking competition, where as part of the programme, inmate participants are also given the opportunity to cook and have the food delivered to their families.For one inmate participant, his passion for cooking began even before he was incarcerated.Mark has been interested in cooking since young and helped out at our restaurants when he was around 10 years old, recalls his mother, Mdm Tan, as she bites into his fried fish. Hes very particular when it comes to food presentation you can see it in his cooking. Hes cooked and sliced his fish beautifully. The colour and cut on his vegetables are good too.The pineapple rice, she pauses and reminisces. Its our familys specialty.Thus, when Mark was jailed in 2018 for drug offences, it broke her heart. Im not young anymore, and hes going in for quite some time. Ive felt lonelier these past two years, but I keep myself busy by working at the restaurants. I cant wait to invite him back home.Although Mark had committed drug offences, Mdm Tan maintains that he is a filial son. He would check up on her during her visits, asking her if she had enough money to spend and reminded her to eat and sleep well. But above all, he always would always ask her to wait for him to come out.As mothers, we just want the best for you, so please spend your time in prison well. Thats all we ask for. said Mdm Tan.While his days in the kitchen differ slightly now, it is evident that Mark still possesses the same burning passion and skill behind bars. He has also done well enough to top his cluster in this years Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition and will move on to compete for the winning spot against five finalists from the other clusters.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

caption: Many Singaporeans have encountered tough times during the COVID-19 pandemic. One such group is the families and children of our offenders.To show support and care towards them, 110 care packs comprising necessities, vouchers and a set of storybooks kindly donated by , were packed by residents from Selarang Halfway House. These care packs will be delivered to beneficiaries of the Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) by , a delivery company founded by an ex-offender.The care packs were made possible from generous individuals and corporates such as Baker McKenzie Wong & Leow.Ms Celeste Ang, Principal at Baker Mckenzie Wong & Leow said: "This is a tough time for everyone in Singapore, and we are all facing the same COVID-19 challenges from multiple aspects. As a long-time partner of Yellow Ribbon Singapore, we are very happy to be given the opportunity to participate in sponsoring the care packs for the beneficiaries." To find out more on how you can do your part to support the Yellow Ribbon Fund, please visit SGUnited

caption: "I hope ex-offenders will have the determination and keep it in mind that there are no quick paths to success. Everything must be done step by step, said Kelvin, one of the award recipients for the Yellow Ribbon Celebrating Second Chances Awards Ceremony.Being incarcerated for 13 years did not deter Kelvin from being a better person. Kelvin now works with various halfway houses, the Red Cross and government agencies and churches across China, Taiwan and Hong Kong on anti-drug movements and rehabilitation and reintegration initiatives for ex-offenders.He shares that in his spare time, he volunteers with SPS by sharing his story and participating in counselling sessions to help troubled inmates. He conducts bible studies and counselling for former drug addicts at The Helping Hand Halfway house. Kelvin feels that because of his experiences, he is better able to connect with these communities and is well-trusted by those he interacts with.SG4SecondChances

caption: At the Yellow Ribbon Community Project Awards and Appreciation Luncheon today, grassroots volunteers were recognised for their contributions and support towards the families of inmates and ex-offenders. The event was graced by Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance, Mr Heng Swee Keat.From its humble beginning in 2010 with 8 participating divisions, the Yellow Ribbon Community Project has now expanded to a total of 89 divisions today. In his speech, DPM Heng mentioned that, From less than 100 volunteers in 2010, there are now more than 1000 of you trained to carry out this important work. Through your combined efforts over the years, you have reached out to more than 10,000 families. You have made a difference to countless lives, so well done!Volunteers play an important role by providing care, support and encouragement to inmates, ex-offenders and their family members. Thank you to the grassroots volunteers for the work that you do it is the small acts of kindness that make a huge impact in the lives of others. SG4SecondChances

Rehabilitation and reintegration is not easy. It requires the collective effort of everyone involved." sg4secondchances

caption: Through strong family support and perseverance, Mr Mohamed Nor Bin Ismail has successfully remained crime and drug-free for the past 18 years. He is also a successful entrepreneur, having started his own wedding and catering business. Mr Mohamed is a recipient at the Yellow Ribbon Celebrating Second Chances award ceremony, which will be held this Saturday, 12th October. Mr Mohamed, who volunteers at the Jamiyah Halfway House () during his free time, credits his late mother as someone who motivated him to turn his life around. He said: "I told my late mother that one day I would make her proud of me. I'm happy and proud to be receiving an award from the Yellow Ribbon Project, as it will serve as an example to others to believe in themselves because nothing is impossible." caption: We're delighted to share a secret little treat that's been baking in our ovens this past week: Finisher Cookies for all runners of this year's Yellow Ribbon Prison Run! caption: James (not his real name) used to be an ex-secret society member who started consuming drugs at the age of 16. "When I go inside prison, the most affected people were my families, especially my son [who] came to ask me, Dad, when are you going to come out?," said James. Now, at 46, James has turned over a new leaf and works at a logistic company as a supervisor. During his time in prison, James attended the "Manalive" programme, which helped him overcome his violent tendencies. Today, he is a dedicated volunteer with Industrial & Services Co-operative Society Ltd (ISCOS) and currently visits Changi Prison twice a month to share his story with other inmates so as to inspire and help them with their rehabilitation journey.Kudos to James for being an inspiration to others SG4SecondChances

caption: The Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Network first started in 2000 with a goal of working with community partners to improve the rehabilitative and reintegrative efforts for ex-offenders.Ms Shanthi Pandian, Director of CARE Network Office, Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE), said: "There are a lot of challenges that the ex-offenders faces once they are released from prison and back into society. There is a need to ensure that the transition is eased and there is enough scaffolding and support from the community to help the ex-offender reintegrate successfully and help him start his life again." SG4SecondChances

There is a need to ensure that the transition is eased and there is enough scaffolding and support from the community to help the ex-offender reintegrate successfully and help him start his life again." SG4SecondChances

caption: After managing to escape the gallows, Azahari served his final 20 years in prison since he was 20 years old and was released in 2014. He had been in and out of prison since a young age of 16 for a total of 4 times, and said I grew up in prison, it was my kind of environment. However, nearing his release date, he reflected on all the years he wasted during his incarcerations, which led him to join prison school. After taking his O levels, he was motivated, I thought to myself, "Hey, I can do this! and did well for his A levels.After he was released, he was supported by the Yellow Ribbon Fund STAR Bursary for his Diploma in Chemical Engineering at Singapore Polytechnic, and graduated in September 2018, defying odds and continuing to strive for excellence. SG4SecondChances

caption: In partnership with the Singapore Chefs' Association, the Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition took place this afternoon in Changi Prison, eight years since the last competition in 2011.The event was graced by guest-of-honour, Senior Minister of State, Ministry of Trade and Industry & Ministry of Education, Mr Chee Hong Tat said "In partnership with The Singapore Chef Association, the Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition aims to equip offenders with skills relevant to the Food & Beverage Industry to enhance their employability after their release. Through this event, we hope to generate greater awareness for second chances." The top 3 finalist teams of inmates worked in pairs to cook the ultimate dish based on the theme of "My Family's Recipe". Unknown to them, their family members were invited in secret to witness their cooking through a live feed. As a form of appreciation to their families, participants served their dishes personally to their family members, strengthening the bond with their family through a shared love of food. SG4SecondChances

caption: Even with a job, ex-offenders may face challenges in transiting from the prisons to employment back in society. The Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises provides Job Retention support by assigning a Job Coach to each ex-offender for up to 12 months after their release. Mr Paul Teng, Assistant Director of Retention Support, Reintegration Division, SCORE, added that job coaches act as an important bridge to help both the ex-offenders and employers understand each others expectations, difficulties and perspectives. Job Coaches engage ex-offenders at their workplace regularly to provide support and set goals with them. This helps them to cope with the demands from the new job and work environment. If ex-offenders have any work related issues, the job coaches will work closely with employers and supervisors to help the ex-offenders resolve it. With stable employment and strong support network, the ex-offender is better able to reintegrate back into society and lead crime free lives. SG4secondchances

caption: [Love And Second Chances] When Alvin Chiong was 15, he worked as a plumber to earn some pocket money. While repairing broken pipes and fixing clogged toilets, a girl named Mei caught his eye, however he was too shy to approach her. He spent the next few months calling 50 different telephone numbers written across his trousers to look for Mei, which he eventually found after much difficulty, and started courting her. After 10 years of dating, they got married in 1997.However things soured in 2007 when Mei caught him red-handed consuming drugs at home. That was when she decided to take their sons and leave him for good. In 2008, with the intention of starting anew, he checked himself into a halfway house. It was only during his third stint in that halfway house that he turned over a new leaf. During the three years at the halfway house, he found religion, companionship and eventually went on to become an employee at the halfway house. By 2014, he felt empowered enough to leave the halfway house and devoted his Saturdays with Mei and his boys. His Sundays were reserved for church and volunteering with the Singapore Anti-Narcotics Association, where Alvin conducts faith-based counselling programmes in prison.As time went on, Alvin and Mei realized that their feelings for each other had never faded. Alvin proposed to Mei again in 2016, and they remarried within the same year. Here at the Yellow Ribbon Project, we couldn't be happier to celebrate stories of SecondChances. Congratulations to Alvin and Mei and thank you for sharing your love story with us! SG4SecondChances valentinesday2019

Here at the Yellow Ribbon Project, we couldn't be happier to celebrate stories of Second Chances. Congratulations to the couple and thank you for sharing your love story with us! SG4SecondChances valentinesday2019

caption: Ten years ago, Augustine Jadyn Ng used to destroy his body with drugs and went on the wrong path. He was then sentenced to the Reformative Training Centre where he did two stints that spanned for about 4.5 years. However, this did not deter him from completing his education through the Yellow Ribbon Star Bursary and landing himself a marketing role in a law firm. Making it a point to thank everyone who helped him, Jadyn paid it forward by volunteering for the Yellow Ribbon Community Project and helping those who were in a similar position. This year, he was accepted in the Singapore University of Social Sciences for the Law programme and hopes to become a lawyer in the future. 10yearchallenge YRconfessions glowup

caption: A new Yellow Ribbon Community Project (YRCP) initiative was launched on Saturday where over 400 school-going children of offenders received Back to School packs worth $50. These packs comprise a school bag, vouchers and stationery. A personalised letter written by the incarcerated parent will also be included in the pack to provide encouragement and to foster stronger parent-child bonds. The school bags are sponsored by the Yellow Ribbon Fund.Guest-of-Honour Mr Amrin Amin, Senior Parliamentary Secretary at the Ministry of Home Affairs and the Ministry of Health, unveiled the new initiative and together with Mrs Josephine Teo , 2nd Minister for Home Affairs and Advisor to Bishan North Grassroots Organisations, distributed the packs to beneficiaries present at the event. Following the launch, grassroots volunteers will begin distributing these packs to families of the offenders in their respective constituencies. This initiative will act as an added touchpoint for YRCP volunteers to engage and connect with the children, alleviate the financial burden on the family and prepare the children for the new school year. SG4SecondChances

caption: Artist mentor and Nanyang Academy of Fine Art lecturer Edwin Ho, was one of the artist mentors for the recent Yellow Ribbon Project Community Art Exhibition (YRCAE) which took place at Raffles City Shopping Centre recently.We spoke with Edwin about his personal interactions with the inmate artists and why he thinks helping inmates and ex-offenders are worth it. Having worked with inmates for the past eight years, he only had praise to share. "I have personally seen four inmates change their lives, I have seen them renounce their old habits and vow to change." Sharing more about his role as an artist mentor, he takes it upon himself to walk with, lead and guide them on the path to rehabilitation through art. One thing he laments that, "whenever I meet the new artists, the thing they lack most is confidence". Edwin also described how the inmate artists gain confidence when their works are displayed at such events like the YRCAE, knowing that distinguished guest view their works.His advice to artist mentors? "Be passionate and walk with them (inmates)". Listen and understand where they come from and help them to express themselves through art. SG4SecondChances

caption: Ahmad was struggling with two jobs to support his six children. When Ahmad was first sentenced, his biggest worry was his six children that he was leaving behind. But all his worries were lifted when he was selected for the Development and Reintegration Programme (DRP). The programme, run jointly by the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) and the Association of Muslim Professionals (AMP), provides support for Malay-Muslim offenders and their families, from the in-care stage when the offender is first incarcerated, to a period of up to 12 months after the offenders release. In-care support includes offenders undergoing the Personal Development Programme, a 10-session programme focusing on the socio-educational development of Malay-Muslim offenders, with a religious element. After-care support includes providing casework services to the family of these offenders, with the intent of enabling their families to become self-reliant.While he was incarcerated, one of Ahmad's constant worries was his children. To facilitate his reintegration, case worker from AMP enrolled his children into student care and then collaborated with Social Service Office and SPS to ensure he had employment upon release. They also facilitated financial assistance for his parents and arranged for religious classes for him to attend when he came out. By leveraging on various agencies to come together and provide holistic support, this enables Ahmad to focus on his rehabilitation and reintegration journey upon his release. "I am thankful to be in this programme as they rendered support so that the needs of my family are taken care of," Ahmad said. Through the assistance given by the DRP, Ahmad was then able to find his footing and turn his life around. He is now better able to cope and ensure that the needs of his children are met. YRConfessions

caption: The idea to offer inmates a chance to study for a diploma in Prison School sprouted from a learning journey to Prison School. The lecturers from Ngee Ann Polytechnic (NP) were touched by the inmates determination to study and decided to launch the Diploma in Business Practice (International Supply Chain Management) course in Prison School.However, things were not easy for the inmate students as they have a different learning environment compared to the other students out there. The inmate students would seek opportunities to clarify their doubts in class as they do not have access to electronic devices after their lesson. They cherish the lesson time as they do not have access to tuition nor peer learning., Mr Wong Yew Fei, lecturer at Ngee Ann Polytechnic and at Prison School.Inmates who have successfully enrolled in the Diploma course will remain registered as NP students after their release. Students who require financial assistance to continue the course after their release can approach Yellow Ribbon Fund or Singapore Aftercare Association.SG4SecondChances

caption: Grassroots leader, previous Chairman of Tampines-Changkat Division and a Yellow Ribbon Champion. Suzana Ahmad, shared with us how her volunteering journey began with the Yellow Ribbon Project - a visit to Changi Prison five years ago which sparked her desire to help families affected by incarceration. Now as a Yellow Ribbon Champion, Suzana coordinates and manages the volunteers within her grassroots division. Having been a volunteer with the Yellow Ribbon Community Project for the past five years, Suzana has a selfless heart for reaching out to the loved ones of the incarcerated and providing support and assistance to help them cope. Tears flow as she recounts particular cases which have made lasting impressions. One of her first cases was when she organised Iftar (an evening meal Muslims end their daily Ramadan fast at sunset) for a family who had been coping with the husband's incarceration for the past 14 years. Help does not come only in terms of food but also education and counselling. Both spouses and children, who have been emotionally affected by the parent's incarceration, are given attention in the form of tutors or people whom they can confide in. "(The) Yellow Ribbon Community Project is a bridge to reach out to the beneficiaries. There are a lot of people out there who need help and this project helps to open that door to helping them." Having many volunteers ready to help is a huge step in helping ex-offenders re-integrate back into society. SG4SecondChances

caption: During the Yellow Ribbon Conference (YRC) held last month, we sat down with Deputy Chief Executive of the Society of Rehabilitation and Crime Prevention, Hong Kong, Anthea Lee for a quick chat. First held in 2005, the aim of the conference was to provide professionals with a platform to share best practices and discuss the rehabilitation, and reintegration of inmates and ex-offenders. Anthea, who is also the General Manager of Bright Services Company Limited (BSC), manages a social enterprise under the Society of Rehabilitation And Crime Prevention, which includes maintenance services, as well as a central kitchen and restaurant. Speaking with Anthea quickly broadened our perspectives on helping ex-offenders internationally. She compared the situation in Hong Kong to one not much different than the one we have in Singapore. Describing that community support was key, she highlighted that community and family support were paramount in re-integrating ex-offenders. Having been to Japan, China and Taiwan, Anthea shared that these countries are aware and very supportive of the cause we work for! Let's keep up the good work with our international and national partners in the spirit of promoting a more accepting society!MotivationalMonday SG4SecondChances

caption: Ole Hessel, Director of High:five, has a goal of cooperating with relevant parties in order to establish sustainable solutions that create value for at-risk young people, private businesses, and the public sector. Having worked as a police officer from 1981 to 2006, he became Director of High:five, a newly established organisation tasked to create jobs for former offenders. Today, besides job creation, the 22-member strong High:five advocates for and drives public-private cooperation that prepares prisoners and ex-offenders for jobs. "Motivation is the key thing here. Everybody dreams of a good life. If people are sitting in prisons thinking "It's impossible for me to get a good life" then they wont dream of getting out... [I was] invited as a speaker to inspire Singapore but [I] find we are the ones being inspired." sg4secondchances

caption: When asked about Mr N Chandramohans reputation, Mr Abdul Aziz replied with a laugh, At first, arrogant ah, stern also. But this is what I heard from my colleagues. Now, thats not the case, hes one of my good friends, BFF lah. During the recent Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) Appreciation Awards ceremony, Mr Chandramohan received the Model Supervisor Award. To be considered eligible, supervisors have to be nominated by ex-offenders under their charge. This award recognises supervisors for going the extra mile in coaching and supporting ex-offenders. Aziz, who nominated Mr Chandra, appreciated his supervisor for being ready to lend a helping hand whenever he faced problems. My boss is very kind-hearted and willing to listen. He encourages me to do a good job and I am very happy to work for him. We would like to wish Mr Abdul Aziz Md Sani and Mr N. Chandramohan the very best as they continue on their respective paths!SG4SecondChances

caption: "Why do you think ex-offenders deserve a second chance?" "Actually, you shouldn't say second chances. You should say, they need chances. They need all the chances they can get and they need all the help they can get from any organisation or community. Just remind yourself that you're (ex-offenders) in this life for a reason. Everyone is special in their own way so find the special reason you are here for and make a difference in your life." SG4SecondChances MotivationalMonday

caption: Transitions: Crossroads & Choices - the theme for the 11th Yellow Ribbon Community Art Exhibition (YR CAE), was launched today by President Halimah Yacob at the Raffles City Shopping Centre. For the first time, a special exhibition featuring illustrations by children of inmates will also be on display. Titled The Invisible Victims of Incarceration, the exhibition includes drawings that show the hopes and aspirations of children under the CapitaLand-YRF Children Support Programme..This years exhibition showcased mixed medium artworks that were created by inmates, reflecting the challenges and transitions experienced in their own rehabilitation journey. In addition, members of the public can support the Yellow Ribbon cause by adopting the art pieces at the exhibition. Proceeds from the adoption will go towards the Yellow Ribbon Fund, which supports a variety of rehabilitation and reintegration programmes and services for inmates, ex-offenders, and their families..If youll be in the area from the 22nd to 30th September, come on down to see these wonderful art pieces! Check out our event page for more info. SG4SecondChances

Titled The Invisible Victims of Incarceration, the exhibition includes drawings that show the hopes and aspirations of children under the CapitaLand-YRF Children Support Programme. caption: "Why do you think ex-offenders deserve a second chance?" "I think the label of 'ex-offender' is very telling, it sets them apart from everyone else. At the end of the day, we're all humans. If we are able to make mistakes and rectify them, why not [ex-offenders] as well?" SG4SecondChances MotivationalMonday

caption: Close to 400 Yellow Ribbon Community Project (YRCP) volunteers across various grassroots divisions were recognised for their contribution and support towards the families of inmates and ex-offenders at the seventh Yellow Ribbon Community Project Awards and Appreciation Luncheon today. The event was graced by Guest-of-Honour Mr K Shanmugam, Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law.In his speech, Minister Shanmugam noted that of the 9000 offenders entering into prison, more than 80% have drug antecedents. He also regarded that while the Singapore Prison Service is committed to the rehabilitation of offenders under their custody, community involvement is critical in supporting the families who are affected by the incarceration of a loved one. Minister Shanmugam also announced the launch of a new YRCP initiative, where approximately 900 booster packs will be distributed to the families of offenders to provide further support, as well as to create an additional touchpoint to strengthen bonds between these families and grassroots volunteers. Kudos to the grassroots volunteers for the work that they do it is small acts of kindness that transform the world. SG4SecondChances

caption: The Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) honoured 88 organisations and individuals at the SCORE Appreciation Awards Ceremony today..Themed Strengthening Collaboration, Enhancing Skills this year, the SCORE Appreciation Awards Ceremony recognised the invaluable contributions of various partners who support SCORE in rebuilding the lives of ex-offenders by helping them enhance their employability potential..Graced by Guest-of-Honour, Mr Ong Ye Kung, Minister for Education, the event also showcased the testimonies of some of the award winners and reformed ex-offenders. Through these anecdotes, the event hopes to inspire many others to come forward to build a more inclusive and supportive working environment for ex-offenders.SG4SecondChances
cleaned_caption: The Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) honoured 88 organisations and individuals at the SCORE Appreciation Awards Ceremony today. Themed Strengthening Collaboration, Enhancing Skills this year, the SCORE Appreciation Awards Ceremony recognised the invaluable contributions of various partners who support SCORE in rebuilding the lives of ex-offenders by helping them enhance their employability potential. Graced by Guest-of-Honour, the Minister for Education, the event also showcased the testimonies of some of the award winners and reformed ex-offenders. Through these anecdotes, the event hopes to inspire many others to come forward to build a more inclusive and supportive working environment for ex-offenders. SG4SecondChances

caption: "Why do you think ex-offenders deserve a second chance?"."There are a lot of reason why people offend, there are a lot more reason why they should reintegrate back into society. There are also lot of success stories out there so we need to give ex-offenders the chance and avenues to succeed.".MotivationalMonday SG4SecondChances
cleaned_caption: Why do you think ex-offenders deserve a second chance? There are a lot of reasons why people offend, there are a lot more reasons why they should reintegrate back into society. There are also a lot of success stories out there so we need to give ex-offenders the chance and avenues to succeed. #MotivationalMonday #SG4SecondChances

caption: As part of SCORE, Ravi Subramanian, Senior Director, Reintegration & Aftercare of the Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) looks after the reintegration and aftercare for ex-offenders. He also looks to enhance the employability of inmates through skills training to prepare inmates for reintegration..Speaking about how the CARE Network has to stay relevant in this day and age, he shared that members of the CARE Network "must constantly update themselves with new competencies to best handle reintegration and rehabilitation of ex-offenders"..SG4SecondChances
cleaned_caption: As part of SCORE, Senior Director, Reintegration & Aftercare of the Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) looks after the reintegration and aftercare for ex-offenders. He also looks to enhance the employability of inmates through skills training to prepare inmates for reintegration. Speaking about how the CARE Network has to stay relevant in this day and age, he shared that members of the CARE Network "must constantly update themselves with new competencies to best handle reintegration and rehabilitation of ex-offenders."

caption: Andy Lee, Acting Head, Aftercare Department, Singapore Anti-Narcotics Association (SANA) shared about how SANA plays an active role in supporting drug abusers in their rehabilitation journey under the CARE Network..Andy shared about how he had been a Senior Social Worker before and some of the recurring issues that these ex-offenders face include accommodation, employment, and family support. Andy hopes to see more outreach programmes to engage families. "It is especially important to reach out to families as it is not just one person but a whole system and so, trying to help the families as a whole instead of just one person is one thing we are trying to do..SG4SecondChances MotivationalMonday
cleaned_caption: Acting Head, Aftercare Department, Singapore Anti-Narcotics Association (SANA) shared about how SANA plays an active role in supporting drug abusers in their rehabilitation journey under the CARE Network. He shared about how he had been a Senior Social Worker before and some of the recurring issues that these ex-offenders face include accommodation, employment, and family support. He hopes to see more outreach programmes to engage families. "It is especially important to reach out to families as it is not just one person but a whole system and so, trying to help the families as a whole instead of just one person is one thing we are trying to do." #SG4SecondChances #MotivationalMonday

caption: Thomas Liao, Social Work Associate at Fei Yue Community Services has a comeback story with a happy ending that inspires everyone who reads it.."I have been helped by many people so I also understand the importance of acceptance and helping someone. Through these experiences, I hope (that) I can also help and share this experience with other people"..Read more about Thomas on our Facebook page!.SG4SecondChances

caption: It was the look of extreme disappointment on his mother's face that propelled Mr Ramli Bin Abdullah to change for the better. "I had disappointed her for so many times and this was going to be the last." In 2012, he finally decided to turn his life around for the sake of his mother, now 74, who had been the only one in the family who visited him in prison..Taking it upon himself to prove his naysayers wrong about how a "leopard never changes it's spots", Ramli does his best everyday to show that anyone can change, by volunteering as a preventive drug education speaker with Central Narcotics Bureau, a citizen-on-patrol with Singapore Police Force and one he's most proud of, a Befriender with Singapore Prison Services (SPS)..SG4SecondChances
cleaned_caption: It was the look of extreme disappointment on his mother's face that propelled him to change for the better. "I had disappointed her for so many times and this was going to be the last." In 2012, he finally decided to turn his life around for the sake of his mother, now 74, who had been the only one in the family who visited him in prison. Taking it upon himself to prove his naysayers wrong about how a "leopard never changes its spots," he does his best every day to show that anyone can change, by volunteering as a preventive drug education speaker with Central Narcotics Bureau, a citizen-on-patrol with Singapore Police Force, and one he's most proud of, a Befriender with Singapore Prison Services.

caption: During the CARE Network Workplan Seminar yesterday, Senior Parliamentary Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and Health, Mr Amrin Amin highlighted the strong aftercare eco-system, supported by both professionals and volunteers..Having grown from eight key partners to over 100 partners to date, the CARE Network continues to play a key role in bringing together various agencies to innovate and look for novel ways to approach aftercare..Along with our volunteers, who are crucial to the success of our programmes, the CARE Network will continue to find ways to enhance our programmes in order to tackle the changing needs and demographics of beneficiaries..SG4SecondChances
cleaned_caption: During the CARE Network Workplan Seminar yesterday, Senior Parliamentary Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and Health highlighted the strong aftercare eco-system, supported by both professionals and volunteers. Having grown from eight key partners to over 100 partners to date, the CARE Network continues to play a key role in bringing together various agencies to innovate and look for novel ways to approach aftercare. Along with our volunteers, who are crucial to the success of our programmes, the CARE Network will continue to find ways to enhance our programmes in order to tackle the changing needs and demographics of beneficiaries. #SG4SecondChances

caption: A total of 108 artworks will be displayed at the tenth edition of the Yellow Ribbon Community Art Exhibition at the Singapore Art Museum. Themed For Better Endings and New Beginnings, the exhibition expresses the inmates resolve in righting past wrongs, and starting anew with their loved ones.The exhibition will run from 7 October 22 October 2017, 10 am to 7 pm from Saturdays to Thursdays and 10 am to 9 pm on Fridays. Admission is free.
